qas.question: Why are hydrocarbon pesticides not excreted?
How are levels of pesticides higher going up the food chain?
The movement of pesticides from wawrme to cooler climates is called what?
How could pesticides travel over hundreds of miles?
How long does an animal store fat when it has a healthy diet?
What regions have larger concentrations of marine animals?
What group is able to store fat more quickly?
In what area do fish-eating birds usually live?
How far do fish-eating birds need to fly for a meal?

context: Since chlorinated hydrocarbon pesticides <a0_0>dissolve in fats<a0_0/> and are not excreted, organisms tend to retain them <b4_0>almost indefinitely<b4_0/>. <a1_0>Biological magnification<a1_0/> is the process whereby these chlorinated hydrocarbons (pesticides) are more concentrated at each level of the food chain. Among marine animals, pesticide concentrations are higher in <b6_0>carnivorous fishes<b6_0/>, and even more so in the fish-eating birds and mammals at the top of the ecological pyramid. <a2_0>Global distillation<a2_0/> is the process whereby pesticides are transported from warmer to <b5_0>colder regions<b5_0/> of the Earth, in particular the Poles and <b7_0>mountain tops<b7_0/>. Pesticides that evaporate into the atmosphere at relatively high temperature can be carried <b8_0>considerable distances<b8_0/> (thousands of kilometers) by <a3_0>the wind<a3_0/> to an area of lower temperature, where they condense and are carried back to the ground in rain or snow.
